comments.commentBody: Here's one of the many problems for Trump with this kind of deal: for each of the 800 hundred or so jobs he "saved" there are 700 jobs down the road he didn't. It looks a lot like he is picking winners and losers based on his own crass political calculations. So he gained a couple hundred fans. It is not a repeatable event, and in the end taxpayers will foot the bill, transferring money from the public good to corporate profits. How any thinking person can view this as anything other than another publicity stunt is beyond me. He wouldn't be able to pull off his slights of hand without the willing participation of the press.

Let's keep some perspective. Trump has promised to create 25 million jobs. So he would have to do that 25,000 times. Also the economy has created an average of 180,000 jobs a month in 2016. So he would have to do that more than 180 times a month to do better.

This would be funny if it wasn't so preposterous.  Is the government going to buy 208,000 jobs per month for the next four years to prop up the Trumpster's empty and impossible promises?  Wow!  What could possibly go wrong.  A fake presidency to go along with a fake campaign.  And when it all starts to fall apart, will he push the nuclear button to hush his critics?

Plaudits to Trump for taking concrete action to save American jobs. I remember taking a college course 20 years ago where one of the topics was whether the government should intervene to foster American industry. China and Europe (think Airbus) have done it for decades to the detriment of American industry, which must compete without government assistance. If this new Trump model helps American industry and jobs, then I'm all for it. We must do more to protect American industry and jobs.

Headline should read "Trump Saves Jobs Right Under Obama's Nose".    Liberals are outraged that Trump saved jobs in the Midwest and are stretching hard to paint it as irrelevant and unsustainable.   Then Bernie "never had a real job" Sanders weighed in with a ridiculous op-ed that helps explain why he couldn't beat Clinton.   The anger and spite on the left is overwhelming.   I'm sure the folks in Indiana see the left rooting against them and their families.  Charles Blow nearly had convulsions railing against the jobs and Trump on CNN tonight.   Oh, and the $7mm in tax credits over 10 years = dwarfed by the state taxes those jobs will pay, just do the math.   So jobs kept with less net tax income to the state, versus jobs lost and no tax income = win for Indiana too.   Liberals should stay away from math, it is not their friend.

As I grew up in Mexico in the 80's, I remember a Mexican Economy that was closed to the world, as it opened to the world in the early 90's most of it's companies struggled and died as they realized that because of years of living in protectionism, they had become sloppy, expensive and non competitive. The US was the example of competitive advantage, do what you are most productive and competitive and source what doesn't.
Now I see a reversal of roles. I see a United States acting more as the Mexican economy in the 70's and 80's and Mexico as the United States then.

Carrier now will not be as competitive as it could by not saving the 65 million dollars it was supposed to save with relocating. they are not alone, competition exists, and most probably another player will take advantage of that.
Carrier could have invested those 65 million in the US in R&D and probably create more than the 800 jobs it was meant to relocate.

Let's not be naive. In order to get companies to keep, or create, jobs in the U.S. we're going to have use incentives and penalties. We have to make companies WANT to stay here and keep and create jobs here, and the way that companies "want" is by making it economically viable. That's what we had before Reaganomics, a.k.a. "trickle down", was foisted upon us.

To work right and be sustainable, these incentives/penalties have to be fair, and not be tilted towards one end or the other. I'm afraid that with Trump making the deals, they're going to be heavily slanted towards his wealthy cronies (and family), and will ultimately become just a different version of "trickle down". But we'll have to wait and see. For now, a company was convinced that it made more economic sense for them to keep jobs here, so let's count that as a win for now. But as every baseball fan knows: it's a long season.

Saving 1,100 jobs from leaving the American shores is a good story any day. However, Mr. Trump’s unspoken “incentive”, besides the $7 million tax rebates from the state of Indiana, is troublesome. Mr. Trump never tires of mentioning his negotiating skills. These are the skills that are not talked about openly but could become a norm for Mr. Trump to entice businesses to bend to his will. In certain New York “business” segments it is common to make an offer that one cannot refuse.  These are often friendly offers as the offering party kisses you on cheek even if you do not want the deal. Looks like United Technology got an offer that it just could not refuse. And many such offers await companies and organizations that initially do not bend to Mr. Trump’s will. I am sure the free market Republicans are rejoicing on this new way of doing business.

Our local suburban political hacks do this all the time under the guise of "industrial development agencies," or IDAs. In response to companies' hollow threats to move or eliminate jobs, the IDAs award big tax breaks. The retained "jobs" are often low-level, minimum wage or part-time and the companies think nothing of reneging on their promises. The taxpayers are left holding the bag, just as they will under the Carrier deal.

This is an early taste of the way our new President intends to dupe the working class, just as he's done to his business adversaries and his customers time and time again with one broken promise after another. This is Trump University all over again, except on a much larger scale.

Republicans have long advised that it is not the job of the government to pick 'winners and losers'. A criticism levied at President Obama for subsidizing Solyndra. A bet that didn't pay off. Now, with Trumps intervention with Carrier, he opens the Government's (taxpayer's) coffers to the threat of corporate blackmail. Not my idea of 'ending crony capitalism' or 'draining the swamp'. The message has been broadcast far and wide, "taxpayers are ready to subsidize you" even if you never contemplated building a plant in Mexico, just rattle that cage and you'll get their attention. However, offering $7 million dollars over ten years to save 800 jobs at one plant is hardly a message of hope for the nation.

If people could just suspend, for a day at least, the antagonism of an election that is over, really over, then maybe the simple fact that 1100 jobs were saved  and the several thousand family members who will benefit is just that and the President-Elect deserves the credit. Every thinking person knows this is not an economic miracle for the country and hard work for the President and congress lie ahead and nothing is guaranteed. A promise made was a promise kept and maybe he's not the ogre many believe.

This is not a win.  There are still about 1,000 jobs leaving for Mexico, what about them?  What about the many millions of taxpayer dollars being doled out either as a bribe by the government or being extorted by Carrier(take your pick), so that only half the jobs stay in Indiana.  I'm in total agreement with Sen. Sanders regarding this charade, this token act of random kindness(Ha!!) by Carrier and its parent company.  No one in the media spoke to the 1,000 people being laid off , only to the survivors.  Trump's got them where he wants them- using them as his propaganda tools.

This is the part where the anger of the Trump supporters towards the government causes me so much confusion that I end up in a pretzel-logic death trap when trying to understand it

As best I can tell, for the majority of the Trump supporters everything is about jobs and keeping the government out of businesses so that the free market can work as designed by letting businesses create job growth, with the chief complaints directed at the government being related to i.) excessive regulations that stifle job growth, and ii.) taxes that are then redistributed to people who did not earn the money.

So has President-elect Trump (heavy-handedly) stepped in to save jobs interfering with the free market or not?

(And did he focus on Carrier during the campaign precisely because Pence is/was Governor of Indiana and he could benefit from a little early PEOTUS marketing success via crony-capitalism or not?)

Are the middle class free-market supporters recognizing that corporations are using automation and foreign labor to eliminate the middle-class $50,000-$60,0000 a year jobs that require only a high school diploma and now turning to the government and asking them to step in and regulate or not?

Are the good people of Indiana now going to watch their hard earned income be redistributed to Carrier in the form of taxes or not?

Are both Carrier and the employees of Carrier who are fortunate enough to keep their jobs now receiving a government sponsored handout or not?

There is not a person in Washington, DC who would blink if we gave $7 million in foreign aid to a developing country for job creation. Why blink now when that same amount is used to help American workers? That's how I want my tax dollars spent. The Democrats should never have neglected their middle class base.

The targeting of Carrier by President-elect Trump during the campaign season seems to be a calculated position aimed at exploiting his running mate's ties and connections in the good state of Indiana, knowing that as PEOTUS he could stand to benefit from a little early promotional success story.

In the future when Vice-president elect Mike Pence is no longer governor of Indiana and President-elect Trump and the government decide to step in to regulate and save jobs, who will decide what jobs get saved and when intervention is appropriate and necessary? Is this the first official sign that crony-capitalism is now the order of the day and law of the land?

There is a new sheriff in town, folks, and all that glitters ain't gold, but all that is gold might end up being the sheriff's.

There is a certain danger to over-analyzing a situation. There are still millions of Americans (and billions around the world) who are trying to understand why Mr. Trump defeated Secretary Clinton for the Presidency. But for better or worse, millions of Americans voted for Mr. Trump because he promised that he would protect their jobs.

And in this case, that promise was delivered.

Bribing one company with taxpayer dollars in order to save a handful of low wage jobs temporarily isnt a policy. Its a bandaid solution that's completely meaningless in the long run. What's Trump going to do -- go state by state, company by company offering giveaways? Pure garbage.

The Trump bashing is getting tiresome.  He somehow kept a number of jobs in the country and that is meaningful to those people.  The idea that blue collar jobs are leaving the country because of technology is absurd.  They are leaving the country because of lower wages.  Ford is leaving for Mexico to save thirty or forty dollars an hour in wages and benefits.  There are responsibilities to communities that transcend profit.  Ironically, France, a country that provides excellent benefits to the populace is the most efficient country on earth.  Germany pays extraordinary wages but is efficient and profitable as well.  Corporate greed has taken over in the United States and the working class has suffered, despite empty unemployment claims. Now Trump should go after GE, Apple,...

Maybe the Opinion page should be Carrier Jobs, Saved by Common Sense.  The average salary of these workers creates state and local income tax.  The $700K a year tax savings will still net the state and local governments $1.5M.  Plus, sales tax, excise tax, property tax on housing, and spending that will keep the jobs at CVS, Walgreens, automobiles, repairs. Plus, Carrier pays for health care and retirement.  What kind of math are they teaching at the NYT?  Additionally, Indy will get a new update to plant.

The Free Market is not some Deus ex Machina which comes down from heaven to save the world. The Free Market requires control or it will destroy workers in a country that emphasizes unregulated Free Market,

Free Market seek the highest profits and cheapest labor which in the end will lead to the gutting of many businesses by sending jobs to cheap labor companies and returning high profits to investor and leaving everyone else out in the cold.

Free Markets were held up as an economic panacea for countries. It is only after several decades of free markets that we discover the price if very high and has ripped apart the social fabric of the country.

Free Markets must be regulated, We must insist that AMerican companies keep most of their jobs in America to support the economy of the country and the people who live in it.

We must not be conned into believing that free markets are wonderful - they are mostly wonderful for corporations and not so wonderful for workers. In many countries the Free Market is out of control and must be reined in. Companies who indulge in off-shoring must pay a price for the whole they leave in the economy. They must repatriate profits to their home countries, and be prepared to retrain worker or provide them with adequate pensions and health care.

Free Markets must not be allowed to run wild and trample the domestic economy was they do now. We all know what NAFTA did to American. This is why there will be no TPP or TTIP.

He made a deal to save several hundred jobs at a factory and cut out the union in the negotiations.  The union will have less influence in that factory now because it wasn't the union that saved those jobs.
It's interesting that the president-elect took action while the president sat on his hands.

It was interesting to hear that Trump said that he had forgotten that he had made this "promise" to save the Carrier jobs. Interesting, because he repeated it many times. It goes to show that Trump just says whatever comes to his mind without meaning it. I'm happy for the 800 people that will keep their jobs for now, but it was done on the backs of taxpayers.
http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-donald-trump-...

Doesn’t this deal have a tinge of Socialism where the tax payers are instrumental in keeping the 800 jobs here, not that I am against Socialism, I benefit from the Socialist VA. However, it seems hypocritical for these Capitalists Icons, Pence & Trump to use a little Socialism to prove they van save jobs.I’m not against tax credits if the Corporations share their profits with the workers, which would only be fair.

This is puzzling. Trump has *zero* authority until Jan 20th to sign anything on behalf of the US. Even then, he has no authority to single handedly sign off an appropriation.

This was entirely the govt of Indiana, which didn't need to wait until Trump won to pull the trigger on this -- they've been talking to Carrier for a while. So why is *Trump* taking the credit for something *Pence* did?
